title: TV star Steve Backshall surprises conservation project with £10k prize and top National Lottery award
text:

It's an incredible project at the forefront of the fight to save some of England’s most at-risk species – and now Back From The Brink has received a major national award.

Topping the public vote for Best Heritage Project in the 25 Birthday National Lottery Awards, the conservation initiative will pick up a cash prize of £10,000 to go with their iconic National Lottery Awards trophy.

Back From The Brink, a four-year programme, is made up of 19 projects working at more than 40 sites across England.

Their aim is to save 20 of the country’s most at-risk species from extinction, with a further 200 to benefit.

“Coming first in a public vote was one of the most remarkable aspects of the whole thing,” said programme manager Rich Howorth.

“For such a long time, conservation has been a niche area but the way this award came about, through a public vote covering both cultural and natural heritage, proves that people are increasingly interested in nature and the importance of biodiversity.

“Our involvement in the competition helped us gain a huge amount of exposure, which is a wonderful result for the project.”

The star-studded 25 Birthday National Lottery Awards, honouring the people and projects using National Lottery funding to do extraordinary things in their communities, will be on BBC One in November.

Rich, who accepted the award on behalf of his team at the glittering awards ceremony, said high-profile endorsements were making an impact, too.

Actor Laurence Fox presented the award on the night, with TV nature presenter Steve Backshall on hand last month to deliver the news Back From The Brink had won.

“Laurence Fox clearly had a genuine interest in the work we’re doing,” said Rich. “That matters, and we felt a real boost when Steve came out to tell the team we’d won. He did some great filming which will go out when the awards are broadcast in November.

“Chris Packham gave us his support as well, and all that goes a long way in getting the message out there about how important our work is.

“Already we’ve managed to bring back the chequered skipper butterfly which disappeared from the UK in 1976.

“We brought some females back from Belgium two years ago, and earlier this year we had our first crop of English-born ones in more than 40 years.”

Other creatures the team hopes to save include the narrow-headed ant and ladybird spider.

Rich added: “The narrow-headed ant is now completely restricted to Devon by the A38 dual carriageway. It’s the only location we have them in England.

“The hope is we can extract some from the colony and move them to new sites, growing the population that way. The techniques are quite experimental.

“Then in Dorset we have the poster girl of the project, the ladybird spider. It’s a beautiful animal and we’re working very hard to up the numbers there, too.”

The 25 Birthday National Lottery Awards, hosted by Ore Oduba, will be on BBC One on November 19.
description: Back from the Brink fights to save the country’s most at-risk species from extinction
